unnormalised: School exams, *yaar*, they're like the ultimate rollercoaster, aren’t they? From the moment the syllabus drops, usually around April or May, it’s a non-stop ride of prep, anxiety, and last-minute cramming. Remember those days leading up to the CBSE Class 10 boards? I do! It felt like the entire country was collectively holding its breath. My friend, Rohan, was aiming for 90+% so he was pulling all-nighters.
normalised: School exams, yaar, they are like the ultimate rollercoaster, are not they? From the moment the syllabus drops, usually around April or May, it is a non-stop ride of prep, anxiety, and last-minute cramming. Remember those days leading up to the C-B-S-E Class ten boards? I do! It felt like the entire country was collectively holding its breath. My friend, Rohan, was aiming for ninety plus percent so he was pulling all-nighters.

unnormalised: The thing about school exams is that they’re not just about rote learning, though that definitely plays a role, especially in subjects like History. You've got to understand concepts, know how to apply them, and write coherent answers in a limited timeframe. Take Maths, for instance. Memorizing formulas is only half the battle. You need to solve problems, practice different variations, and for goodness sake, avoid silly mistakes! I remember losing marks in my ICSE exams just 'cause I messed up the sign! -_-

You need to solve problems, practice different variations, and for goodness sake, avoid silly mistakes! I remember losing marks in my I-C-S-E exams just because I messed up the sign! face with a tear.

unnormalised: Then there’s the sheer variety of exams. We have the aforementioned board exams, of course – CBSE, ICSE, state boards like the Maharashtra SSC which happens around March time. Then there are unit tests every few weeks, half-yearly exams, and pre-boards, all building up to the big one. It's like a constant barrage of tests designed to break us down… and maybe build us up too?
normalised: Then there is the sheer variety of exams. We have the aforementioned board exams, of course – C-B-S-E, I-C-S-E, state boards like the Maharashtra S-S-C which happens around March time. Then there are unit tests every few weeks, half-yearly exams, and pre-boards, all building up to the big one. It is like a constant barrage of tests designed to break us down… and maybe build us up too?

unnormalised: And let's not forget the pressure from parents and teachers. "Sharma ji ka beta" always gets good marks, right? Suddenly, every family gathering turns into an interrogation session about your studies. My dad used to ask me every single evening how much I’d studied that day. It was exhausting! Teachers, bless their souls, just want the best for you, but sometimes their expectations can be overwhelming. Especially with the competition these days. Getting a seat in a good college after your 12th exams requires like, 98% or higher.

Getting a seat in a good college after your twelfth exams requires like, ninety eight percent or higher.

unnormalised: The exam hall itself is a different beast altogether. That nervous energy in the air is palpable. You see some students frantically flipping through their notes until the very last second. Others are just staring blankly ahead, resigned to their fate. The moment the invigilator hands out the question paper feels like the start of a race against time. For me, I would always make sure I knew exactly what time it was. I brought my own watch and checked it religiously. So annoying, but I couldn't help it.

unnormalised: But hey, it's not all doom and gloom! Exams can also be a great motivator to learn, improve, and push yourself beyond your comfort zone. And when you finally finish that last exam and walk out of the hall, there's no feeling quite like it. The sense of relief, the anticipation of results, and the freedom to finally relax. I remember after my 12th boards, my friends and I booked a trip to Goa. Best. Holiday. Ever.

unnormalised: So, yeah, school exams are tough, stressful, and sometimes even traumatizing. But they're also a rite of passage, a challenge that shapes us, and a stepping stone towards our future. Plus, they give us some pretty hilarious stories to tell later on, don't they? Like the time I accidentally wrote the wrong year on my answer sheet… talk about a facepalm moment! *Chalta hai*.
